segments.text: I have listed here a ball breaker signaling device.
Well, that was kind of fun.
And I must say, as usual, these things have a little more implication than they sound like.
That was Art Maxwell and me, I think.
At any rate, at that time there was a lot of importance of measuring, taking cores on the ocean bottom and taking temperature out.
a gradient in the ocean bottom, which required very precise lowering of devices at great depths in the ocean, temperature probes.
And it was important to know when you were on bottom.
And these were depths of 4,000 fathom or so, you see, 3,000 fathom.
Well, you've got a lot of cable out.
There's a fairly light instrument on the bottom of it.
There's really no way to tell when you're on the bottom of it.
So you needed something that told you when you hit bottom.
Well, there was quite a lot of possibilities of how you did this.
And there have certainly been much more sophisticated devices since.
But this, we rigged up one real fast.
And it was a glass ball with a hammer and a trip.
And when it hit bottom, the hammer came down and presumably smashed the glass ball.

and the ocean finding itself unsupported, since there's now a hole in the middle of it at 2,000 or 3,000, fathom rushes in, and the noise it makes when it meets itself, coming from all sides, is considerable.
There's a lot of power in there.
And you hear this bang on the surface, but you know you've hit bottom.
Well, it turned out to be much more difficult to break these damn glass balls.
I suspected it.
Then you'd have a hammer that just smashed into pieces on the surface, but under this pressure, it didn't do anything.
It just bounced.

make a point on the hammer big hammer you know dropping make a point on the hammer the hammer would sometimes go into the ball and seal other times it would go in knock a shell off and the ball would be intact when you came up uh sometimes the ball would crack all the pieces but not break it would all be held together by the pressure well we finally made the proper kind of point that it always always broke the ball but this of course had led

That paper, incidentally, then, and our remarks about the difficulty of breaking the ball have led to the utilization of glass capsules in underwater vehicles and spherical capsules in underwater instruments of all sorts because glass obviously requires quite different properties under these very high pressures.
Excuse me.
I have high-speed plankton.
Sampler in 1958.
Yeah, that was a kind of fun device.
When we were first starting out, 1958?
We designed that much earlier than that.
That was when the paper came out, I guess.
It came out years later.
That was back in 1951 or so, or 53 maybe.
It was a torpedo-shaped plankton sampler that could be towed at high speed at considerable depth.
And it had a neat little recorder in it that told you how deep it was and how much water was passing through it at each depth.
It worked very well.
It was used for quite a few years.
I have, in 1966, an Isaacs Brown opening-closing trawl.
That's just a modification of the Medwater trawl that allows you to open and close it at some depth.
Now, the last two things I would like some elaboration on.
1968, a deep sea observational camera system.
Well, over a series of years we developed these cameras.
They were free fall cameras that you could chuck over the ship's side.
And they went to increasing sophistication.
We designed them in several different forms.
They went to the bottom.
They usually had a bait in the foreground somewhere, a mass of fish or something, and they sat down there taking pictures every five minutes or ten minutes.
Sometimes still pictures, sometimes movies, motion pictures, and sometimes stereo motion pictures.
We had some interesting stereo motion pictures.
And we discovered a great deal about the deep benthic fauna and how it behaved and
what the distribution of these creatures were, how they probably searched for the food, and a whole different food web, you see, of very active deep creatures, yes.
I think I'll try to revise that program because it's kind of a natural for a cooperation with small coastal countries because the cameras can be operated from unspecialized vehicles.
They can be dropped over the side and sections taken down across the shelf and find out what really lives in these deeps.

We find, for instance, along this coast that some of the commercial fish of British Columbia and southern Alaska and Washington, probably their main population is down here off Baja California at great depths.
They're creatures of the cold, dark waters, and they merely outcrop up in the Arctic regions or near Arctic regions.
And that's where the principal commercial fishery is based.
But the population itself extends to increasing depths down farther and farther and closer to the equator.
We find a big population of great arctic sharks off the Baja California coast, for example.
A shark very much like the Icelandic or Greenland shark.
Huge one.
Lots of shrimp.
We'd land deep lobsters.
We'd find all sorts of things.
When did you first become interested in photography?
You mean in underwater photography?
In underwater photography and above water photography.
Well, I became much impressed by the competency of first-rate cameras to record things at Bikini, I think.
Well, before that.
I was in charge of the photography of the two A-bomb shots in 1946.

And the fact that these big aerial cameras would allow you to place in space and in position ships and explosive phenomena and so on and so forth, I thought was, when they were rigidly based on land, was a very powerful technique.
I'd used these kinds of cameras in determining the motion of an amphibious craft in the surf zone.
In that early work at Berkeley, you see, by mounting cameras on shore and aiming them aerial cameras, big mapping aerial cameras on shore aimed at amphibious craft coming through the surf.
You then could position a craft exactly in space continuously, see just what its motions were.
You could even, on a big craft, you could even measure the bending of the hull.
So I was much impressed by the competency of first class mapping cameras used in those kind of modes.
And of course, I've always wanted to see what did the ocean do with a dead whale on its bottom?
What in the devil does it do with it?
It increases the food supply in square miles for years in a dead whale.
It must be adapted to utilize it.
And so it turns out it is.
Ravelle tapped me on that one.
Because I'd been doing this radio-controlled photography.
We not only had two aerial cameras shooting at amphibious craft in the surf, but a radio-controlled camera and a planar blimp up above photographing simultaneously with radio control.
She triggered the shots, automatic system.
And then Revell asked you then to go to Bikini and mount cameras, which would be in charge of the photography.
In charge of photography, right.
Of the land-based photography.
Well, the radio-controlled photography.
And did you use the same techniques there that you had used?
Essentially, yeah.
Did you make any substantial changes?
Oh, well, of course it had to have lots more backups and things because there was no going back and repairing the cameras.
And so we built the towers, and we designed the backups.
And the backups were, of course, it was uncertain at that time what would happen to radio signals at the time of an atomic explosion.
So we had not only a central radio triggering synchronizers for the total cameras, airborne and land,
but we had
back up individual timers on each camera.
So if it failed to get its pulses, it asked for another one.
And if it got another one and didn't respond, then it took its own picture anyway.
And as a matter of fact, that saved our neck just at the instant of the explosion.
That's what Ravel said, exactly what happened.
He did?
Yeah.
When was that?
When I interviewed him.
He suggested that the camera work here was not only splendid, but it involved innovation which had not been done before in camera work.
Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.
That's right.
And so exactly what happened?
Why did the cameras fail the first time?
Oh, just because of the tremendous electrostatic charge that is built up at that instance.
You see a vast amount of static just for that instant shock.
So we got pictures.
The bomb had gone off underwater.
The bottom of the fleet was lit up, and the shockwave had not yet arrived at the surface.
And 30 fathom of water.
The bottom of the fleet is lit, and there's not a pimple on the surface yet.
That's pretty remarkable photography.
Now, was it contact here on Bikini Atoll?
Is this the contact that brings you to Scripps Institution?
This contact with Revelle here?
No, I don't know.
The first time I ever remember Revelle was an interesting case, as a matter of fact.
I'd built the first of these sea sleds.
Mm-hmm.
And we were at Morro Bay, California.
And I had built it, and then I was out on the beach, and we were going to test it for the first time.
We had a duck, and we had a big spool of rope, just rope, manila rope.
And I had attached this, and I had two helpers, two duck drivers.
I had attached this roll, and we had it on a standard.
And I said, well, we just started in the surf.
First time we ever started a sea sled.
And the commandant of the little naval base there came down and says, there's an important young lieutenant at the train in San Luis Obispo.
You're supposed to go pick up.
I'd never heard of Revell before.
So I got in the car and went down.
and picked up this young, slender, tall lieutenant and brought him back.
And we came down on the beach.
And here are these two guys.
I told him about this sea sledge taking a line through the search.
Here are these two guys, 6,000 feet of line, standing out in the ocean.
The cable spool has pulled off the standards.
They've got an oar shoved through the cable spool.
It's plowing the sand down towards the beach, you see.
So obviously, they're being pulled into the surf, both of them.
I grabbed the duck then and ran a wire out from the winch at the stern of it and got hold of it.
They hadn't had time to do this.
So it was an interesting first introduction to Ravel and our work there.
He was immensely impressed by that damn sea sled, I must say.
It's kind of a mysterious line going out into the ocean, these two guys.
And of course, I'm obviously shocked and excited.
So that was my first introduction to him.
We then took him out in the surf in the duck.
He'd never been out in a DUKW, a wheeled vehicle.
Marvelous vehicles.
Marvelous.
We never really managed to sink one in any reasonable sort of surf.
I have a picture of one with a 28-foot breaker coming up on it.
I was in.
I survived it, obviously.
Well, anyway, so that was my first introduction to Rivelle.
Maybe 1945, I don't know when it was.
He was just organizing what was going on.
Marvelous man.
And, well, who specifically taps you to do the photography at Bikini?
He does, doesn't he?
Rivelle, yeah.
He does, all right.
And then after photography there, and...
I got interested in radioactivity.
OK. And waves.
In fact, that's one of the reasons we did the photography.
It turned out it really was necessary to place all the ships in the exact position.
But then, of course, the main purpose was the wave theory, what kind of explosive waves were produced by these sorts of things.
And that's what we followed then on the bigger shots later, the waves.
What sort of wave did you expect?
from that.
Well, just about what came, what were produced, yeah.
Some people argue that the wave would be untold feet high.
Well, those were interesting days when we first shot off the big ones out there, because it wasn't a bit clear that the atoll would necessarily not collapse.
And we had some of the best world famous, Kishtiakowsky, the famous soil machination
You see, a coral atoll is really kind of a barrel full of mud, a thin shell, a brittle shell.
And it's clear that coral atolls only exist where there are no earthquakes.
So there was a real question.
Was the thing stable or not?
The bomb itself probably couldn't make a highly destructive wave.
But over the atoll, it might in critical depth and deep water.
But as part of the atoll collapsed, then the amount of energy they got linked into a wave was gigantic.
We surely didn't know whether that would take place or not.
And there lies a tale of where we almost evacuated the Pacific Basin by accident.
Someday we'll go into that one.
Was that the cloud mist that appeared?
No, no.
No, no.
I don't know if this tale has ever quite been told.
This was at Ivy Mike, the first big gauge bomb.
And it was shot off on an island in the north of Bikini, northwest of Bikini.
Totally obliterated the island.
And at that time, we didn't know whether it would produce a huge wave or not.
So we set off on a seamount about 700 fathom deep.
We mounted two floating wave gauges.
And we had the Horizon, one of our ships, and Walter Monk was there, and Bill Bascom was there, and a fellow by the name of Commander Monk Hendricks.
And we had these two, and we were going to stay with them 12 minutes, which was after the bomb went off.
and see if there was going to be a great change in water level.
And we had a set of signals.
And everything was set up to start the evacuation of Pacific Coast cities if we had a big one.
Well, the bomb went off.
We stayed there the 12 minutes.
The cloud was overhead at this time.
We'd practiced getting these skiffs back ashore, aboard.
Not our moorings, just the skiffs we ran.
So we watched that first H-bomb from skiffs 26 miles away.
and the open water with the horizon was well away.

Well, we had practiced getting those skiffs back aboard and us aboard, and the earliest we could do it was something like 15 minutes, but with that cloud overhead, we got it done in something like five, you know.
Every hand was there pulling.
Well, we then got in the fallout,

We took more fallout than any fixed point on the Earth's surface has ever gotten, because we were conned into following a path that eventually turned out we were following the point of maximum fallout for something like 17 hours.
Anyway, days later, we got back to the skiffs and picked them up.
One minute after we left that skiff, one of these moorings showed.

a record of a 50-foot wave something had gone wrong with it what had happened was the the pressure gauge had not locked into its position and and had suddenly let loose and slid down the cable 50 feet but of course we wouldn't have known that it went up 50 feet and stayed there
But if we'd been there and seen the 50-foot wave, we would have certainly called for the evacuation of the Pacific cities of the North Pacific.
And the fiasco would have been absolutely gigantic.
Scripps' name would have been totally mud.
When did you come to Scripps?
Well, I oscillated between Scripps and Berkeley for a year or more in about 1948 or thereabouts.
I first applied to Scripps in 1936 for a job.
was here.
I had been commercial fishing.
I had gotten a lot of questions about my mind about the oceans.
I asked very puzzling things when I was still puzzling.
I had written a letter to Scripps asking why these things were taking place.
I got an answer which really didn't address the questions I'd asked.
Just like even today, why you get all kinds of questions from fishermen and one thing or another.
So I thought, boy, those guys need some help down there.
But it seems to me, I can't answer these kinds of questions, so I applied for a job.
It took me 10 years to get here.
was director then, just freshly director in 1936.
Did it seem to you as if Scripps' institution functioned better when it was smaller?
Well, it depends what you mean by better.
It was a hell of a lot more fun, I guess.
In many ways, there was more rapport, and there was more of a spirit of adventure, I think.
I was thinking about interchange of ideas.
I'm shocked that a guy comes to you and says, how about a troll?
You're involved with the monk.
And did you seem to have more exchange with your colleagues?
Was it compartmentalized then?
Is it compartmentalized now?
Well, I think in any oceanographic institution, this fundamentally has to be interdisciplinary.
And I think it perpetually tends to crystallize into special forms of each of the disciplines again, you see.
There's a perpetual necessity to be breaking up.
There's a polymerization that goes on, a crystallization that has to be continuously combated.
People like to talk to people who are in their same field.
There's no question about it.
Yet, really, the penetration and understanding of the universe in general, and the oceans in particular, and the planet in particular, certainly requires communication of all sorts.
And yet,
I think the ideal has to be accumulation around temporary nuclei that then break up and form new associations, and that's a hard thing to form.
A follow-up on this.
Now, when Ravel goes to Pakistan, don't you go with him?
No, I have been with him.
You have been with him to Pakistan.
Well, that's what I meant on his first trip to Pakistan to study the soils.
Weren't you part of that?
Sure.
How would you be involved in that?
What was your connection with this solization process?
Well, obviously, the salt eventually had its origins in the oceans.
I mean, as Ravel says, if you want to understand a planet with oceans, you also have to understand a planet without them.
That's why you should study Mars.
Kind of control, huh?
One planet with, one planet without.
That's not very, from that viewpoint, it's not much of a stretch to say you ought to also look at the doabs of West Pakistan, where the problem is salt.
And I had worked some on the salt of the Colorado River and various other things.
I was interested in halophytic plants.
I think they're really a vast
potential halophytic plants of this world, the ones that are perfectly capable, the higher plants that are perfectly capable of living in seawater.
Totally unexplored.
Almost totally unexplored.
We have no idea what the total genetics of all the halophytic plants of this world are.
Every time we even look at it, we find new ones.
Halophytic avocado, for instance.
Fortunellas, legumes.
You see.
Our crop plants, the crop plants on which man depends for his entire existence, strangely were all developed by prehistoric man.
We have never developed a crop plant with any consequence.
In historic times, we've made improvements, or sort of improvement.
But all the principal tremendous selections of polyploidy and everything are made by primitive man.
The only thing we've developed in historic times are grapefruit and pustule sprouts.
And, you know, nobody's going to feed the human race on those.
So the whole curious matter of increasing salination around the world, the increased need for utilization of seawater for agriculture,
of aquaculture and so forth.

And this vast array of plants, higher plants, that know perfectly well how to desalinate seawater all by themselves using sunlight at high-level energy rather than the degraded form we can use it in, has really received no attention.
It's something Texas A&M ought to get into.
Was this what originally attracted you to your work on the Colorado River, or was it vice versa?
Well, I got interested in the Colorado River for a very curious reason.
I was plotting the total dissolved solids of the Colorado River one time, and several other rivers, including the Indus, as a function of stream flow, annual stream flow.
And it turns out that instead of that line of plot of total dissolved solids per year and total water flow per year,
extrapolating through the zero-zero axis, which is, say, zero dissolved solids transported at zero flow, it goes through the dissolved solid axis at rather high level.
It's an inclined line, which says, in the case of the Colorado, that at zero flow, it's transporting 3,600,000 tons of salt.
Well, the only possible explanation for such a decent river, like the Mississippi, goes through the zero-zero axis.
But both the Indus and the Colorado do not.
The only possible explanation for this is that there are brine springs feeding into the rivers.
Brine springs, not salt springs, but concentrated brines, which are continuously flowing.
So that as the river goes down a year of low flow, the slant is higher.
We start hunting for those springs, which we assume must exist.
And we found none of them in the hydrological literature at all.
We found them in the anthropological literature.
The Indians knew about these brine springs flowing into Colorado.
And the first one we looked for was a great series of volcano-like structures of pure salt with pure saturated brine flowing down into Colorado.
600,000 tons a year.
And I thought, you know, the hydrological mythology is the river supplies you with water that God has determined the quality of.
That is now your problem.
Nobody ever inquires as to how it got that quality.
So now here's just this one spring.
600,000 tons is enough to put 15,000 acres out of existence every year by salination.
But it's a small flow.
Why not build a little brick retainer and pump the damn stuff back up on the mesa or inject it into the ground and keep it out of the Colorado?
Can't get anybody interested in that.
Reclamation Department doesn't do that sort of thing.
Agriculture Department care less.
That's not part of their problem.
And so it still flows into the Colorado as far as I know.
And there are undoubtedly six more like that.
And out of curiosity, you think anthropological sites can locate these?
That's how we locate it.
That's marvelous.

Because the Indians had a real mythology about the trek, the salt trek, which was kind of a young manhood trek to go down in this great canyon and climb down these cliffs and gather the salt and bring it back.
And that's all recorded in 1896.
That's where we found it.
We even found the old ladder that the first man who went down there early in this century had built to get down one of these cliffs, all full of salt drift and crystals of salt.
What made you decide to check anthropological literature?
Well, it's obvious that if you're going to find out what the Indian names of these damn streams are, they'd surely know whether they had salt in them or not.
And, of course, the Indus does the same thing.
I mean, it's easy.
There's a place called Salt Mountain or Salt Hill.
It's by Sargodha.
And it flows into the Indus.
It's salt water.
Anyway, that's only part of it.
But it's interesting, it seems to me.
And it's an interesting commentary on our bureaucracy.
